In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

In Julia, you can use the package Dates to manipulate dates and times. Here is a function that accomplishes what was asked:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if typeof(dt) != DateTime
        throw(ArgumentError("Provided argument must be of type DateTime"))
    end
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end
```
In the function above, `Hour` is a function from Dates.jl that takes an integer and returns a Period of time that is equivalent to that number of hours. It then adds this period to the input DateTime object. 

The argument `; bump=3` in the function signature means that if you don't provide a second argument when calling the function, it will use 3 as the default value for `bump`.
